settings.text: All sustainable journeys must start from somewhere, and sometimes it can be hard to find all the information at once. As you continue to embark on the journey to a more sustainable way of life, we have compiled this glossary to educate and inform you!

settings.title: Biodegradable
settings.answer: Capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms.

settings.title: Biofuel
settings.answer: Any fuel that is derived from biomass—that is, plant or algae material or animal waste.

settings.title: Biomaterial
settings.answer: Materials that come from plants, such as cotton, silk, or wood.

settings.title: Biomass
settings.answer: Plant or animal materials used to create energy.

settings.title: Bioplastics
settings.answer: A type of biodegradable plastic derived from biological materials rather than from petroleum, or oil.

settings.title: Byproduct
settings.answer: Excess material produced.

settings.title: Carbon Credits
settings.answer: A permit that allows the company that holds it to emit a certain amount of carbon dioxide or other greenhouse gases.

settings.title: Carbon Emissions
settings.answer: Pollution released into the atmosphere from carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide; often produced by motor vehicles.

settings.title: Carbon Footprint
settings.answer: The amount of carbon dioxide produced by your lifestyle.

settings.title: Carbon Neutral
settings.answer: Producing no net carbon dioxide emissions, especially through planting trees as offsets.

settings.title: Carbon Offset
settings.answer: A measure to offset the emissions of carbon dioxide caused by industrial or other human activity.

settings.title: Circular Sustainability
settings.answer: Creating products that last and can be reused, repaired, and remanufactured.

settings.title: Climate Change
settings.answer: A long-term change in the average weather patterns that define Earth's local, regional and global climates.

settings.title: Climate Positive
settings.answer: Exceeding achieving carbon neutrality by removing additional carbon dioxide from the atmosphere; also referred to as carbon negative.

settings.title: Closed-Loop
settings.answer: A system where everything is recycled and reused.

settings.title: Compostable
settings.answer: A product that can disintegrate into non-toxic, natural elements.

settings.title: Composting
settings.answer: The natural process of recycling organic matter, such as leaves and food scraps, into a valuable fertilizer that can enrich soil and plants.

settings.title: Conservation
settings.answer: The careful maintenance and upkeep of a natural resource to prevent it from disappearing.

settings.title: Deforestation
settings.answer: The purposeful clearing of forested land.

settings.title: Drought
settings.answer: Extremely low rainfall over a prolonged period leading to water shortages.

settings.title: e-Waste (Electronic Waste)
settings.answer: Discarded electrical or electronic devices.

settings.title: Eco-Conscious
settings.answer: The mentality to focus on reducing harm to the environment wherever possible.

settings.title: Eco-Friendly
settings.answer: Not harmful to the environment.

settings.title: Ecoliteracy
settings.answer: the ability to understand the natural systems that make life on earth possible.

settings.title: Ecosystem
settings.answer: A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.

settings.title: End of Life
settings.answer: The point at which a product is no longer useful and the process of reusing, recycling, or disposing of it begins.

settings.title: Endangered Species Act
settings.answer: Works to classify species as threatened or endangered, designating habitat essential for their survival and recovery and ultimately restoring healthy populations of the species to be removed from the list.

settings.title: Energy Efficient
settings.answer: Uses the smallest amount of energy possible to provide power.

settings.title: Environment
settings.answer: the surroundings or conditions in which a person, animal, or plant lives or operates.

settings.title: Environmental Impact
settings.answer: The effect something has on the environment.

settings.title: Enzyme
settings.answer: A substance produced by a living organism that acts as a catalyst to cause a biochemical reaction.

settings.title: Fair Trade
settings.answer: Principles of fair treatment, wages, and safe working conditions for workers.

settings.title: Fossil Fuels
settings.answer: Derived from organic matter such as plants, animals, and microbes. Natural gas, coal, oil, and petroleum are all fossil fuels.

settings.title: Garbage Patches
settings.answer: A popular name for concentrations of marine debris in the North Pacific Ocean.

settings.title: Ghost Nets
settings.answer: Fishing nets that have been abandoned, lost, or discarded, at sea, on beaches, or in harbors.

settings.title: Glucose
settings.answer: A simple sugar that is made by hydrolysis of starch.

settings.title: GMO (Genetically Modified Organism)
settings.answer: A genetically modified organism is a plant, animal, microbe, or other organisms whose genetic makeup has been altered in a laboratory. This creates plants, animals, bacteria, and viruses that don't exist in nature or through traditional crossbreeding.

settings.title: Green
settings.answer: Term used to describe behavior, product, policies, people, etc. that minimize environmental damage.

settings.title: Green Technology
settings.answer: A technology that reduces or prevents the consumption of natural resources.

settings.title: Greenwashing
settings.answer: Misrepresenting something as being “green” when it’s not environmentally sound.

settings.title: Greenhouse Gasses
settings.answer: Gases in Earth's atmosphere that trap heat.

settings.title: Ground Shipping
settings.answer: Ground shipping is a delivery solution that uses existing driving routes for domestic shipments in the US.

settings.title: Hybrid Work
settings.answer: A flexible working model where employees work partly in the physical workplace, and partly remotely – at home or from another workspace.

settings.title: Hydroelectric Energy
settings.answer: The energy of moving water is converted into electricity by generators driven by turbines.

settings.title: Hydrolysis
settings.answer: The chemical breakdown of a compound due to a reaction with water.

settings.title: Incineration
settings.answer: The combustion of substances contained in waste materials. Industrial plants for waste incineration are commonly referred to as waste-to-energy facilities.

settings.title: Landfill
settings.answer: Where waste is buried underground and can pollute groundwater, release greenhouse gases and produce odors.

settings.title: Locally Recyclable
settings.answer: These are items such as paper, magazines cardboard, aluminum, glass, plastic bottles, and more that are able to be recycled at a local facility or recycling center.

settings.title: Microorganism
settings.answer: A microscopic organism, especially a bacterium, virus, or fungus.

settings.title: Monomer
settings.answer: A molecule that can be bonded to other identical molecules to form a polymer.

settings.title: Natural Fibers
settings.answer: Fibers sourced from plants including cotton, flax, hemp, bamboo, sisal, and jute.

settings.title: Naked Packaging
settings.answer: Products that are sold without packaging.

settings.title: Natural Resources
settings.answer: Raw materials supplied by nature.

settings.title: Net-Zero
settings.answer: Achieving a balance between emissions produced and emissions removed from the atmosphere; also known as carbon neutrality.

settings.title: Non-Locally Recyclable
settings.answer: These are items such as beauty products, plastic phone cases, flexible plastic packaging, certain cleaning bottles and products, and more that are not typically accepted by local recycling facilities or centers. These products are indeed recyclable, but they often end up in landfills because recycling them is harder, and requires special services or collection.

settings.title: Organic
settings.answer: Anything that was once a living organism.

settings.title: PLA (Polylactic Acid)
settings.answer: A compostable plastic made with plant sugars, primarily corn.

settings.title: Plant-Based
settings.answer: Consisting largely or solely of vegetables, grains, pulses, or other foods derived from plants, rather than animal products.

settings.title: Polyethylene (PE)
settings.answer: A tough, light, flexible synthetic resin made by polymerizing ethylene, chiefly used for plastic bags, food containers, and other packaging.

settings.title: Polymer
settings.answer: A class of natural or synthetic substances composed of very large molecules.

settings.title: Polymerization
settings.answer: A chemical reaction where monomer molecules join together to form polymer chains.

settings.title: Polypropylene (PP)
settings.answer: One of the most commonly used thermoplastics in the world. Polypropylene uses range from plastic packaging, plastic parts for machinery and equipment, and even fibers and textiles.

settings.title: Polystyrene (PS)
settings.answer: A type of plastic used in everything from plastic cutlery to packing peanuts and construction materials.

settings.title: Post-Consumer Waste
settings.answer: A waste type produced by the end consumer of a material stream; that is, where the waste-producing use did not involve the production of another product.

settings.title: Recycling
settings.answer: The action or process of converting waste into reusable material.

settings.title: Renewable Energy
settings.answer: Electricity from replenishable sources such as geothermal, hydropower, solar, and wind.

settings.title: Reusable
settings.answer: An item that can be used again or more than once.

settings.title: Single-Use
settings.answer: Items used one time and then discarded.

settings.title: Solar Energy
settings.answer: Any type of energy generated by the sun that can be harnessed as a renewable energy source.

settings.title: Sustainable
settings.answer: Meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their needs.

settings.title: Synthetic
settings.answer: Made by chemical bonding, especially to look and act like a natural product.

settings.title: Upcycling
settings.answer: To reuse discarded objects or materials to create a product of higher quality or value than the original.

settings.title: Vegan
settings.answer: Not derived from animals or animal byproducts.

settings.title: Wind Energy
settings.answer: The process of using the wind to generate mechanical or electrical power.

settings.title: Zero-Waste
settings.answer: Avoiding products that create waste to avoid contributing to landfills, incinerators, and waste discarded in nature. Minimal waste is a more realistic term, as it’s impossible to create zero waste.
